newsitem.title: USA: KCBT wheat futures end higher on dryness concerns.
newsitem.headline: KCBT wheat futures end higher on dryness concerns.

text.p: KCBT hard red winter wheat futures settled higher amid concerns over dryness in western portions of the HRW wheat belt, traders said.
"Volumes have been thin. The only story today is some commission house buying... tied to dry weather in the western end of the HRW belt," a KCBT trader said.

Wheat drew support from the National Weather Service's six- to 10-day weather outlook released Monday which predicted above-normal temperatures and normal to below-normal precipitation across much of the HRW wheat growing region.
The weekly state crop reports released Monday showed that the HRW wheat condition declined slightly in Texas and Oklahoma due to dryness. Kansas' crop was mostly unchanged.
KCBT wheat settled 3-1/2 to 5-3/4 cents per bushel higher, with May up 4-1/4 cents at $4.16-1/4. New crop July wheat settled up 5-3/4 cents at $3.91-1/4.

Traders said commodity broker E. D. & F. Man International was a featured player, picking up 1.2 million July bushels. Continental Grain also bought one million July, traders said, and Cargill Investor Services bear-spread 1.3 million May/July at 26 to 27 cents.
